algorithms.name: algorithms/identify a session
algorithms.html:
This algorithm describes how to identify a session out of all the sessions that exist on a user agent. The session identifier is unique within a registrable domain.

Given a URL (url) and session identifier (session identifier), this algorithm returns a device bound session or null if no such session exists.

steps.html: Let domain be the registrable domain of url’s host.
If the user agent’s session store does not contain domain, return null.
Let domain sessions be the user agent’s session store[domain] as a sessions by id map.
Return domain sessions[session identifier] with default null.

algorithms.name: algorithms/determine if a URL is in scope
algorithms.html: This algorithm describes how to determine if a URL is in scope of a device bound session. Given a URL (URL) and device bound session (session), returns "include" if URL is in scope, and "exclude" otherwise.

steps.html: Let scope be session’s session scope.
If scope’s include site is true, return "exclude" if URL’s origin is not same site with scope’s origin.
If scope’s include site is false, return "exclude" if URL’s origin is not same origin with scope’s origin.
If URL matches session’s refresh URL, return "exclude".
For each scope specification in scope’s scope specifications:
Let host pattern be scope specification’s host, and path pattern be scope specification’s path.
If running § 8.4 Identify if a host matches a pattern on URL’s host and host pattern returns false, continue.
If any of the following hold, return scope specification’s type:
ignored: URL’s path is exactly path pattern. path pattern ends in '/' and URL’s path starts with path pattern. URL’s path starts with path pattern followed by a '/'.

steps.html: Return "include".

algorithms.name: algorithms/determine if a request is allowed to trigger refresh
algorithms.html: This algorithm describes how to determine if a request is allowed to trigger refresh for a device bound session. Given a request (request) and device bound session (session), returns "allowed" if request can trigger a refresh, and "disallowed" otherwise.

steps.html: If session’s session scope’s include site is true, and request’s origin is same site with session’s session scope origin, return "allowed".
If session’s session scope’s include site is false, and request’s origin is same origin with session’s session scope origin, return "allowed".
For each initiator pattern in session’s allowed refresh initiators:
If running § 8.4 Identify if a host matches a pattern on request’s origin’s host and initiator pattern returns true, return "allowed".
Return "disallowed".

algorithms.name: algorithms/determine if a host matches a pattern
algorithms.html: This algorithm describes how to determine if a host matches a pattern. It takes as input a host (host) and a string (pattern). It returns true if pattern covers host.

steps.html: If pattern equals '*', return true.
Let host string be the serialized host.
If pattern starts with '*' and host is a domain:
If pattern does not start with '*.', return false.
Return true if host string ends with all but the first character of pattern.
Return true if host string is equal to pattern.

algorithms.name: algorithms/identify a session needing refresh
algorithms.html: Given a request (request), this algorithm describes how to identify a session needing refresh. If any such session exists, it should block request from proceeding.

steps.html: Let domain be the registrable domain of request’s url’s host.
If the user agent’s session store does not contain domain, return null.
Let domain sessions be the user agent’s session store[domain] as a sessions by id map.
For each session in domain sessions:
If session’s expiration timestamp is before the present, remove session from domain sessions and continue.
Let id be session’s session identifier.
If the tuple (domain, id) is in request’s deferred device bound session ids, continue.
Run the steps in § 8.2 Identify if a URL is in scope of a session on request’s URL and session. If the result is not "include", continue.
Run the steps in § 8.3 Identify if a request is allowed to refresh on request and session. If the result is not "allowed", continue.
Run the steps in § 8.6 Identify if missing session credential on request and session’s session credentials. If the result is false, continue.
Add (domain, id) to request’s deferred device bound session ids.
Set session’s expiration timestamp set to a future timestamp. The exact choice of expiration timestamp is left up to the user agent. It is recommended to align with the maximum cookie lifetime.
Return session.
Return null.

algorithms.name: algorithms/identify if a request is missing a session credential
algorithms.html: This algorithm describes how to identify if a request is missing a session credential. Given a request (request) and a list of session credentials (credentials), returns a boolean indicating whether any credential in credentials is missing on request.

steps.html: For each credential in credentials:
If a cookie with credential’s attributes would not be attached to request (see section 5.4 of [COOKIES]), continue.
If request’s header list contains a cookie that satisfies all of the following conditions, continue:
ignored: cookie’s name matches credential’s name. All of the following attributes of cookie match those in credential’s attributes: Domain, Path, Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite.

steps.html: Return true.
Return false.

algorithms.name: algorithms/process a challenge
algorithms.html:
This algorithm describes how to process a challenge received in an HTTP header.

Given a response (response), this algorithm updates the cached challenge for a device bound session.

steps.html: Let header name be "Secure-Session-Challenge".
Let challenge list be the result of executing get a structured field value given header name and "list" from response’s header list.
If challenge list is null, return.
For each (challenge, params) in challenge list:
If the type of challenge is not an sf-string, continue.
Let session id be null.
If params["id"] exists and is an sf-string, set session id to params["id"].
If session id is null, continue.
Let session be the result of running § 8.1 Identify session given response’s URL and session id.
If session is null, continue.
For each credential in session’s session credentials:
If a cookie with credential’s attributes could not be set by response (see section 5.3 of [COOKIES]), continue.
Store challenge as session’s cached challenge to be used next time a DBSC proof is to be sent from this device bound session.
Break.

algorithms.name: algorithms/send a request
algorithms.html:
This algorithm describes how to send a request for a device bound session registration or refresh. It takes as input a request (originating request), an optional key pair, URL (destination), and optional strings session id, challenge, and authorization.

User agents will perform these steps whenever a bound credential is missing, but MAY do this at any time. Sending a request proactively before the bound credential expires can minimize the latency costs of DBSC.

steps.html: The user agent MAY skip this request in order to prevent denial of service for the user or site. For example, this might happen if this session is requesting excessive TPM operations (harming the user) or the refresh endpoint has recently been unreachable (denial of service risk for the site). If the user agent chooses to do this, it should perform the steps of § 8.12 Add debug header with originating request, an appropriate token (see options in § 9.5 `Secure-Session-Skipped` HTTP header field), and session id to indicate this to the site.
Let <var>terminate the session</var> be an algorithm with the following steps:
If session id is null, return.
Remove the session with domain destination’s host’s registrable domain and identifier session id from the user agent’s session store, if such a session if found.
If originating request’s URL’s origin is not same site with destination’s origin, return.
Let session response be null. If challenge or authorization is non-null, let session response be the result of creating a DBSC proof for challenge and authorization.
If key pair and session response are non-null, sign session response with key pair.
Create a request for use in HTTP fetch.
Set request’s method to "POST".
Set request’s URL to destination.
Set request’s redirect mode to "follow".
If session response is non-null, append the header ("Secure-Session-Response", session response) to request’s header list.
If session id is non-null, append the header ("Sec-Secure-Session-Id", session id) to request’s header list.
If authorization is non-null, append the header ("Authorization", authorization) to request’s header list.
Set request’s initiator to originating request’s initiator.
Set request’s origin to originating request’s origin.
Let response be the result of running HTTP fetch for request.
If response is a network error, or response’s status is 407 or 429, return.
If response’s status is at least 300 and below 400, then return.
If response’s status is 403:
If session id is null, return.
Let session be the result of running the steps of § 8.1 Identify session on destination and session id.
If session is null, return.
Otherwise, restart this algorithm with the original inputs, except replacing challenge with session’s cached challenge.
If response’s status is at least 400 and below 500, then terminate the session and return.

If response’s status is at least 500, then return. User agents may choose to trigger a backoff mechanism on subsequent refresh requests on this session, to limit the harm of a temporary outage on the refresh endpoint.
If session id is non-null, and response’s body is empty, return.
Call § 8.9 Create session on response, destination, session id, and key pair.

algorithms.name: create a session
algorithms.html: To create a session due to the response (a response) to a registration request to destination (a URL) for session id (a string or null) with an optional key pair, perform the following steps:

steps.html: Let <var>terminate the session</var> be an algorithm with the following steps:
If session id is null, return.
Remove the session with domain destination’s host’s registrable domain and identifier session id from the user agent’s session store, if such a session if found.
Let JSON session be the result of parsing response’s body as a JSON session instructions. If parsing fails, terminate the session and return. This includes validating all required keys are present.
If JSON session’s continue is false, terminate the session and return.
Let session identifier be JSON session’s session_identifier.
Let JSON scope be JSON session’s scope.
Let origin be an origin constructed from JSON scope’s origin, if present, or the origin of destination if not.
If JSON session’s refresh_url does not have a value, let refresh URL be destination.
Otherwise, let refresh URL be the result of resolving destination with the value of JSON session’s refresh_url.

Perform the following validations. If any fail,
 <var>terminate the session</var> and return.
If session id is non-null, it must match session identifier.
origin must be a valid non-opaque origin.
origin must be same site with destination’s origin.
refresh URL must have scheme HTTPS or be localhost.
refresh URL’s origin must be same site with destination’s origin.
All of the JSON session credentials must not have the attribute "Partitioned".
Let destination domain be the registrable domain of destination’s host.
If the JSON scope’s include_site is true, perform the following validations. If any fail, terminate the session and return.
origin’s host must be equal to destination domain.
If destination domain is equal to the host of destination, skip all remaining validations within this step.
If session id is non-null, skip all remaining validations within this step.
Otherwise, let well known URL be a copy of destination, with the host replaced with destination domain, and the path replaced with "/.well-known/device-bound-sessions".
Let well known response be the result of fetching well known URL.
well known response’s status must be 200.
well known response’s body must be a JSON-encoded dictionary.
well known response’s body must include the key "registering_origins".
The value of the key "registering_origins" must include the origin of destination.
Let session be a new session.
Set session’s session identifier to session identifier.
Set session’s refresh URL to refresh URL.
Set session’s session scope to a new scope with origin origin, and include site the value of JSON scope’s include_site.
For each JSON scope rule in JSON scope’s scope_specification:
Let scope rule be a new scope specification.
Set scope rule’s type to JSON scope rule’s type.
Set scope rule’s host to JSON scope rule’s domain.
Set scope rule’s path to JSON scope rule’s path.
Append scope rule to session’s session scope’s scope specifications.
For each JSON session credential in JSON session’s credentials:
Let session credential be a new session credential.
If JSON session credential’s type is not "cookie", terminate the session and return.
Set session credential’s name be JSON session credential’s name.
Set session credential’s attributes be JSON session credential’s attributes.
Append session credential to session’s session credentials.
Set session’s session key pair to key pair.
Set session’s allowed refresh initiators to JSON session’s allowed_refresh_initiators.
Set session’s expiration timestamp to a future timestamp. The exact choice of expiration timestamp is left up to the user agent. It is recommended to align with the maximum cookie lifetime.
For each credential in session’s session credentials:
If a cookie with credential’s attributes could not be set by response (see section 5.3 of [COOKIES]), continue.
Call terminate the session to remove the existing session.
Set the user agent’s session store[destination domain][session identifier] to session.
Break.
Run § 8.7 Cache challenge on response.

algorithms.name: process a session registration
algorithms.html: To process a session registration due to the response (response) to a request (request), do the following steps:

steps.html: Let header name be "Secure-Session-Registration".
Let registration list be the result of executing get a structured field value given header name and "list" from response’s header list.
If registration list is null, return.
For each (registration entry, params) in registration list:
If registration entry is not an sf-inner-list, continue.
If params["path"] does not exist, or is not of type sf-string, continue.
Let path be params["path"].
Let challenge be null, and let authorization be null.
If either of params["challenge"] or params["authorization"] exist but are not of type sf-string, continue.
If params["challenge"] exists, set challenge to params["challenge"].
If params["authorization"] exists, set authorization to params["authorization"].
Let endpoint be the result of resolving path relative to response’s URL.
Let key pair be the result of running § 8.11 Create session key pair on registration entry, params, and endpoint.
If key pair is "failure", return.
Call § 8.8 Send request with request, key pair, endpoint, session identifier as null, challenge, and authorization.

algorithms.name: create a session key pair
algorithms.html: This algorithm describes how to create a session key pair, including key sharing between a Relying Party and Session Provider. It takes as inputs the registration entry and params of a `Secure-Session-Registration` header and the URL (registration URL) of the registration endpoint. It returns a key pair for use in the session, null to indicate that no key is needed, or the string "failure" to indicate that key pair creation failed.

steps.html: Let algorithm list be an empty list.
For each algorithm in registration entry:
If algorithm is not an sf-token, continue.
If algorithm represents a crypto algorithm supported in `Secure-Session-Registration` and is supported on this client, add algorithm to algorithm list.
If algorithm list is empty, return "failure".

If any of <var>params</var>["provider_key"], <var>params</var>["provider_session_id"], or
 <var>params</var>["provider_url"] exists:
If any of the three keys is missing, return "failure".
Let permission be the result of performing request permission to use for "device-bound-session-key-sharing".
If permission is "denied", return "failure".
Let provider URL be a URL constructed from params["provider_url"].
Let provider origin be the origin of provider URL.
If provider origin is opaque, return "failure".
Let provider domain be the registrable domain of provider URL’s host.
Let provider session identifier be params["provider_session_id"].
Let provider session be the session in the user agent’s session store[provider domain][provider session identifier].
If provider session is null, return "failure".
If provider session’s session scope origin is not same origin with provider origin, return "failure".

If provider session’s session key pair is null, or provider session’s session key pair’s JWK thumbprint (see [RFC7638]) does not match params["provider_key"] when encoded in base64url (see [RFC4648]) without padding, return "failure".
Let provider well known URL be a copy of provider URL, with the path replaced with "/.well-known/device-bound-sessions".
Let provider well known response be the result of fetching provider well known URL. If any of the following hold, return "failure":
ignored: provider well known response’s status is not 200. provider well known response’s body is not a JSON-encoded dictionary. provider well known response’s body contains the key "provider_origin". provider well known response’s body does not include the key "relying_origins". The value of the key "relying_origins" does not include the origin of registration URL.

steps.html: User agents SHOULD place an upper limit on the number of registrable origin labels in "relying_origins" to prevent abuse.
Let relying well known URL be a copy of registration URL, with the path replaced with "/.well-known/device-bound-sessions".
Let relying well known response be the result of fetching relying well known URL. If any of the following hold, return "failure":
ignored: relying well known response’s status is not 200. relying well known response’s body is not a JSON-encoded dictionary. relying well known response’s body contains the key "relying_origins". relying well known response’s body does not include the key "provider_origin". The value of the key "provider_origin" is not the origin of provider URL.

steps.html: Return provider session’s session key pair.
Return a new key pair created for algorithm list, using null if the selected algorithm is "none".

algorithms.name: add the debug header
algorithms.html: In order for sites to understand when the user agent chooses not to apply a session, user agents should add the debug header to a request (request) with an sf-token (token) and string (session id).

steps.html: Let value be an sf-token with value token.
Set the sf-parameter "session_identifier" on value to session id.
Let skipped header value be the result of running the steps of get a structured field value with header name "Secure-Session-Skipped", type "list", and request’s header list.
If skipped header value is null, set it to an empty sf-list.
Append value to skipped header value.
Run the steps of set a structured field value given ("Secure-Session-Skipped", skipped header value) on request’s header list.

algorithms.html: After computing cookies in step 8.21, run § 8.5 Identify session needing refresh. If the resulting session is non-null:

steps.html: Run § 8.8 Send request with httpRequest, the returned session’s session key pair, refresh URL, session identifier, cached challenge, and an empty authorization.
Restart HTTP-network-or-cache fetch with the original inputs.

algorithms.html: This specification also requires two new calls to process the new headers. After step 14 in the current HTTP-network fetch, execute the following step:

steps.html: Run § 8.10 Process session registration and § 8.7 Cache challenge.
